org.jpws.front

Class ObjectChangeListener

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jpws.front.ObjectChangeListener
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.util.EventListener, javax.swing.event.ChangeListener, javax.swing.event.DocumentListener, javax.swing.event.ListSelectionListener, javax.swing.event.TableModelListener, javax.swing.event.TreeModelListener, javax.swing.event.TreeSelectionListener, ActivityListener, ActivitySource, ButtonBarListener

    public class ObjectChangeListener
extends java.lang.Object
implements javax.swing.event.ChangeListener, javax.swing.event.DocumentListener, java.awt.event.ActionListener, ButtonBarListener, javax.swing.event.TreeSelectionListener, javax.swing.event.TreeModelListener, javax.swing.event.ListSelectionListener, javax.swing.event.TableModelListener, ActivityListener, ActivitySource
    This class is at the core of object related user activity tracing in JPWS. It is Janus-headed as it implements both the ActivityListener and ActivitySource interface. It thus serves to handle and multiplex incoming activity events and reach them down to registered listeners. Its second function is to detect "user" activity from certain objects which are registered at the listener (in fact the listener is registered at the objects, but alas..).

    Objects of the following types can be handled:

    AbstractButton, JTabbedPane, JSpinner, JComboBox, JTextComponent, JTree, JTable

    See Also:
    ActivityListener, ActivitySource

      • addAncestor

        public boolean addAncestor(java.awt.Component parent)
        Lets the first ancestor which is an AcitivityListener listen to this activity source. Traverses the hierarchy of ancestors.
        Parameters:
        parent - Component parent component to investigate, may be null
        Returns:
        boolean true == ancestor was found, false == no listener added

      • registerChangeableObject

        public void registerChangeableObject(java.lang.Object c)
        Add this ObjectChangeListener to the parameter object in order to listen to some activity occurring. See the class description for the types (classes) which work with this listener.

        Registering does not need a counterpart.
